content.text: Suspend a mass \(m=100g\) from the spring as shown in Fig. 1.1.
Measure, and record in Table 1.1, the stretched length \(l\) of the spring, as indicated in Fig. 1.1.
Repeat this step for values of \(m=200g\), \(m=300g\), \(m=400g\) and \(m=500g\).
Remove the mass \(m\) from the spring.
Describe a technique you used when measuring the length of the spring, to ensure an accurate reading. You may draw a diagram.
Plot a graph of \(1 / \text{cm}\) (y-axis) against \(m / \text{g}\) (x-axis). Start the axes from the origin (0, 0).
Draw a best-fit straight line. The line might not go through the origin.
Use the graph to determine the length \(l_{0}\) of the spring with no load on it.
[Turn over]
Suspend object \(\mathbf{X}\) from the spring and measure the stretched length \(l_{\chi}\) of the spring.
Use the graph and your value of \(l_{\chi}\), to determine the mass \(m_{\chi}\) of object \(\mathbf{X}\). Show clearly on the graph how you obtained your answer.
Two students measure the mass of another object using the same method and apparatus. One student records the mass as 132.6 g. The other student records the mass as 130 g.
State and explain which answer has the more suitable number of significant figures for this experiment.
[Total: 11]
In this experiment, you will investigate the behaviour of a spring and use it to determine the mass of an object.
A stand and spring have been set up for you.
Refer to Fig. 1.1.
\(\cdot\) Pour \(200cm^{3}\) of hot water into beaker A.
\(\cdot\) Place the thermometer in the water.
\(\cdot\) In the first row of Table 2.1, record the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at time \(t=0\) and immediately start the stop-watch.
\(\cdot\) Record, in Table 2.1, the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at times \(t=30s\), \(t=60s\), \(t=90s\), \(t=120s\), \(t=150s\) and \(t=180s\).
Remove the thermometer from the beaker.
Repeat the procedure in (a) for beaker B.

table.html:
beaker A with insulationbeaker B without insulation
\(t/s\)\(\theta/^{\circ}C\)\(\theta/^{\circ}C\)
0
30
60

content.text: Write a conclusion stating whether the insulation affects the rate of cooling of the water. Justify your answer by referring to values from your results.
Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{1}\) during the first half of the experiment for the water in beaker B. Use your readings for beaker B from Table 2.1 and the equation:
where \(T=90s\) and \(\theta_{0}\) and \(\theta_{90}\) are the temperatures of the water in beaker B at times \(t=0\) and \(t=90s\).
Include the unit.
\[x_{1}=\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\quad[1]\]
Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{2}\) during the second half of the experiment for the water in beaker B. Use your readings for beaker B from Table 2.1 and the equation:
where \(T=90s\) and \(\theta_{90}\) and \(\theta_{180}\) are the temperatures of the water in beaker B at times \(t=90s\) and \(t=180s\).
Include the unit.
\[x_{2}=\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\quad[1]
A student suggests that, for this type of experiment, the temperature of the water in each beaker at time \(t=0\) must be the same for the comparison to be fair.
Use your answers from (d)(i) and (d)(ii) to explain whether this is necessary.
A student wants to eliminate, from the comparison, any thermal energy lost from the surface of the water.
Suggest a change to the equipment which will do that.
You are not required to carry out this additional experiment.
Suggest what effect this change will have on the cooling rates of the water in beaker A and beaker B.
[Total: 11]
In this experiment, you will investigate the effect of insulation on the cooling of water.
Refer to Fig. 2.1.
Beaker A is covered with material that is a thermal insulator.
Beaker B is identical to beaker A but has no insulation.
Place the transparent block approximately in the centre of the ray-trace sheet.
Carefully draw round the block and label the corners \(\mathbf{A}, \mathbf{B}, \mathbf{C}\) and \(\mathbf{D}\) as indicated by Fig. 3.1. Remove the block from the ray-trace sheet.
Draw a normal to line \(\mathbf{A B}\) at a point \(\mathbf{N}\), 2 cm from \(\mathbf{A}\).
Draw a line \(\mathbf{E N}\), as indicated by Fig. 3.1, 8 cm long and at an angle \(\theta=40^{\circ}\) to the normal.

Place two pins \(\mathrm{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{2}\) on line EN, a suitable distance apart for accurate ray tracing. Mark with crosses and label the positions of \(\mathrm{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{2}\) .

View the images of \(\mathrm{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{2}\) through the block, from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 3.1. Place two pins \(\mathrm{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{4}\) so that pins \(\mathrm{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{4}\) and the images of \(\mathrm{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{2}\) all appear exactly one behind the other.
Mark with crosses and label the positions of \(\mathrm{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{4}\) .
Remove the block and pins from the ray- trace sheet.
Draw a line through \(\mathrm{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{4}\) . Extend this line to meet line CD.
Label the point at which this line meets CD with the letter F. Label the lower end of this line with the letter G.
Extend line EN to approximately 5cm below line CD.
Label the point at which this line crosses CD with the letter H. Label the lower end of this line with the letter J.
Measure the acute angle \(\alpha\) between lines CD and GF. An acute angle is an angle less than \(90^{\circ}\) .
Measure the acute angle \(\beta\) between lines CD and JH.
\(\alpha =\)
\(\beta =\)
A student suggests that angle \(\alpha\) should be equal to angle \(\beta\) .
State whether your results support this suggestion. Justify your answer by reference to values from your results.
statement
justification
Draw a new line EN, as indicated by Fig. 3.1, 8 cm long and at an angle \(\theta = 20^{\circ}\) to the normal.
Repeat the steps in (b).
Describe one technique to use in this type of experiment to ensure accurate results.
Write your name, centre number and candidate number on your ray-trace sheet. Tie your ray-trace sheet into this booklet between pages 8 and 9.
Suggest one reason why different students, all doing this experiment carefully, may not obtain identical results.
[Total: 11]
In this experiment, you will investigate the refraction of light by a transparent block.
Use the separate ray-trace sheet provided.
You may refer to Fig. 3.1 for guidance.
A student investigates the resistance of a wire.
Plan an experiment which enables the student to investigate how the length of a wire affects the resistance of the wire.
Resistance \(R\) is calculated from the equation: \(R = \frac{V}{I}\)
where \(V\) is the potential difference (p.d.) across the wire and \(I\) is the current in the wire.
You are **not** required to do the experiment.
The apparatus available includes:
a selection of wires
a variable power supply
an ammeter
a voltmeter.
In your plan:
list any additional apparatus needed
complete Fig. 4.1 to show a voltmeter connected to measure the potential difference across the wire
explain briefly how to do the experiment, including the measurements to take so that the resistance can be determined
state the key variables to keep constant
draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion.
